elements.content: Coordination compounds built of trivalent lanthanide ions have been demonstrated as promising solid-state materials for diverse photoluminescent applications and as attractive magnetic objects with the prospective application in information storage and spintronics. We present a synthetic methodology in which both luminescent and magnetic functionalities are induced within lanthanide-based coordination polymers by the application of hexacyanocobaltate­(III) anions and 3-hydroxypyridine (3-OHpy), both coordinated to 4f-metal ions modulating the lanthanide-centered properties. We report a series of trimetallic cyanido-bridged chains {[EuIII x TbIII 1–x (3-OHpy)2(H2O)4]­[CoIII(CN)6]}·H2O (x = 1, 0.8, 0.5, 0.4, 0.3, 0.2, 0.1, 0; compounds 1, 2, ..., 7, 8). They reveal tunable visible photoluminescence ranging from green, through yellow and orange, to red color depending on the composition of material and the wavelength of UV excitation light. Such multicolored emission is realized by the adjusted ratio between red emissive Eu3+ and green emissive Tb3+ and by the selection of wavelengths of UV light controlling the intensities of Eu- and Tb-based components of visible luminescence. The photoluminescence is enhanced by the energy-transfer (ET) process from [CoIII(CN)6]3– and 3-OHpy to lanthanides, and the efficiencies of ET to Eu and Tb play an important role in the switchable emission. The whole family, 1–8, exhibits temperature-dependent paramagnetism due to the intrinsic property of lanthanide­(3+) ions. Tb-containing 2–8 reveal the field-induced slow relaxation of magnetization due to the magnetic anisotropy of Tb3+. Moreover, the compounds built of large amounts of Tb reveal the double relaxation, the faster of a typical TbIII single-ion origin, and the slower originating from the magnetic dipole–magnetic dipole interactions between neighboring TbIII centers. Compound 2, which can be considered as a magnetically diluted sample, exhibits almost single relaxation process with the thermal energy barrier ΔE/k B of 35.8(6) K and τ0 = 1.1(2) × 10–8 s at H dc = 1500 Oe, indicating a single-molecule magnet behavior.

elements.content: A family of bifunctional photoluminescent and magnetic materials constructed of trimetallic cyanido-bridged chains {[EuIII x TbIII 1−x (3-OHpy)2(H2O)4]­[CoIII(CN)6]}·H2O (x = 0−1) is reported. Under UV excitation, they reveal tunable visible emission, ranging from green, through yellow and orange, to red color depending on the composition of the material and the wavelength of excitation light. This property coexists with the slow magnetic relaxation effects observed due to the magnetically anisotropic TbIII complexes embedded in the diamagnetic heterometallic coordination networks.

This property coexists with the slow magnetic relaxation effects observed due to the magnetically anisotropic TbIII complexes embedded in the diamagnetic heterometallic coordination networks.

elements.content: Trivalent lanthanide ions embedded in coordination systems arouse a considerable scientific interest due to the attractive photoluminescent properties. Lanthanide-based materials found diverse applications as tunable laser systems, light-emitting devices, amplifiers for optical communication, low-energy scintillators, optical storage materials, devices for light conversion, chemical sensors, molecular thermometers, photovoltaic light concentrators, and bioimaging tools. Thus, there is a strong need to search for novel coordination compounds built of 4f-metal ions revealing effective luminescence, in particular such light-emitting functionalities as white light, or multicolored tunable emission, near-infrared phosphorescence, and up-conversion luminescence.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Trivalent lanthanide ions embedded in coordination systems arouse a considerable scientific interest due to the attractive photoluminescent properties. Lanthanide-based materials found diverse applications as tunable laser systems, light-emitting devices, amplifiers for optical communication, low-energy scintillators, optical storage materials, devices for light conversion, chemical sensors, molecular thermometers, photovoltaic light concentrators, and bioimaging tools. Thus, there is a strong need to search for novel coordination compounds built of 4f-metal ions revealing effective luminescence, in particular such light-emitting functionalities as white light, or multicolored tunable emission, near-infrared phosphorescence, and up-conversion luminescence.

elements.content: Complexes of lanthanides are also broadly investigated due to their remarkable magnetic properties. They can exhibit strong magnetic anisotropy leading to slow relaxation of magnetization which is related to the energy barrier (ΔE) of spin inversion. Below blocking temperature, magnetically anisotropic lanthanide-based coordination molecules and chains, named single-molecule magnets (SMMs) and single-chain magnets (SCMs), respectively, show magnetic hysteresis of the molecular origin which opens the applications in high density information storage and molecular spintronics. Lanthanide-based SMMs are constructed of coordination clusters of f-metal ions, and mixed d/f-metal ions, or even mononuclear 4f-metal complexes, often called single-ion magnets (SIMs). Among them, the highest energy barriers were found for DyIII and TbIII, however magnetic anisotropy of other 4f-metals, e.g., ErIII or YbIII, was also explored.

Lanthanide-based SMMs are constructed of coordination clusters of f-metal ions, and mixed d/f-metal ions, or even mononuclear 4f-metal complexes, often called single-ion magnets (SIMs). Among them, the highest energy barriers were found for DyIII and TbIII, however magnetic anisotropy of other 4f-metals, e.g., ErIII or YbIII, was also explored.

elements.content: In pursuit of multifunctional materials, that can give a new quality by combining two or more physical properties, luminescent molecule-based magnets based on lanthanides­(3+) ions appear as a promising idea. Such bifunctionality was realized for magnetically ordered systems built of emissive 4f-metal ions and polycyanidometallates. However, lanthanides­(3+) ions can give only weak magnetic coupling, limiting their application in design of luminescent magnets of high critical temperatures. On the contrary, they offer strong magnetic anisotropy which, together with a diversity of luminescent effects, results in a great potential toward emissive SMMs. In fact, a considerable number of photoluminescent SMMs constructed of DyIII, ErIII, and YbIII complexes were reported.
elements.clean_text: In pursuit of multifunctional materials, that can give a new quality by combining two or more physical properties, luminescent molecule-based magnets based on lanthanides(3+) ions appear as a promising idea. Such bifunctionality was realized for magnetically ordered systems built of emissive 4f-metal ions and polycyanidometallates. However, lanthanides(3+) ions can give only weak magnetic coupling, limiting their application in design of luminescent magnets of high critical temperatures. On the contrary, they offer strong magnetic anisotropy which, together with a diversity of luminescent effects, results in a great potential toward emissive SMMs. In fact, a considerable number of photoluminescent SMMs constructed of DyIII, ErIII, and YbIII complexes were reported.

elements.content: The reports on lanthanide-based SMMs focused the main attention on the correlation between magnetic and optical properties, that is the optical estimation of anisotropic energy barrier, ΔE, from the high-resolution low-temperature emission spectra, while the possibly attractive luminescent effects of lanthanide­(3+) complexes were not explored. In this regard, lately, we decided to take fresh and much more comprehensive approach toward emissive SMMs that truly combines adjustable magnetic characteristics with tunable light-emitting functionalities such as multicolored, white, or near-infrared emission. To achieve this, we explored the rare materials based on bimetallic coordination polymers constructed of emissive lanthanide­(III) complexes combined with red emissive hexacyanocobaltate­(III) anion. Such a synthetic approach is part of a more general methodology of combining 4f metal ions with polycyanidometallates which was realized in our group, and by others, resulting in several types of functional materials with interesting magnetic, optical, and thermal expansion properties.

To achieve this, we explored the rare materials based on bimetallic coordination polymers constructed of emissive lanthanide(III) complexes combined with red emissive hexacyanocobaltate(III) anion. Such a synthetic approach is part of a more general methodology of combining 4f metal ions with polycyanidometallates which was realized in our group, and by others, resulting in several types of functional materials with interesting magnetic, optical, and thermal expansion properties.

elements.content: We have recently prepared DyIII(3-hydroxypyridine)–[CoIII(CN)6]3– material based on bimetallic cyanido-bridged chains which reveals DyIII-centered white light emission coexisting with SMM behavior of strongly anisotropic DyIII complexes with a high thermal energy barrier of 385 K. In this report, we proved that a diamagnetic and red emissive [CoIII(CN)6]3– linker can modulate both the magnetic and optical properties of DyIII, being a good sensitizer for DyIII emission, and extorting the axially elongated geometry of DyIII complexes. Recently, we presented also the layered DyIII(4-hydroxypyridine)–[CoIII(CN)6]3– material in which another attractive luminescent property, that is the excitation switchable emission, originating from the equilibrium between properties of DyIII and organic ligand, can be induced within the cyanido-bridged skeleton, and such a property coexists with a field-induced slow magnetic relaxation. These reports indicated that new bifunctional magneto-luminescent materials can be obtained by rational design from the self-assembly of hexacyanocobaltate­(III) and complexes of lanthanides­(III) with selected organic ligands. Prompted by this discovery, we aimed at the preparation of functional materials combining tunable photoluminescence and SMM behavior that are constructed of EuIII and TbIII complexes which are known to reveal the strongest visible emission among lanthanides, in the red and green range, respectively. While Eu­(3+) ions do not offer interesting magnetic properties due to the diamagnetic 7F0 ground state, Tb­(3+) ions of the 7F6 ground state are often strongly magnetically anisotropic, leading to SMM characteristics with large energy barriers, but their magneto-luminescent potential is not well recognized. Following our recent results on DyIII–[CoIII(CN)6]3– coordination systems, we focused our attention of lanthanide complexes with pyridine-based ligands that are able to induce diverse coordination topologies amending the magnetic and optical functionalities of cyanido-bridged materials. Here, we present the synthesis, crystal structure, and detailed magnetic and optical properties of a unique family of crystalline magneto-luminescent materials constructed of a series of trimetallic cyanido-bridged {[EuIII x TbIII 1–x (3-OHpy)2(H2O)4] [CoIII(CN)6]}·H2O (x = 1, 0.8, 0.5, 0.4, 0.3, 0.2, 0.1, 0; compounds 1, 2, ..., 7, 8; 3-OHpy =3-hydroxypyridine; ) chains combining the field-induced slow magnetic relaxation of TbIII complexes with multicolored photoluminescence tunable both by the Eu/Tb ratio and by wavelength of UV excitation light.

In this report, we proved that a diamagnetic and red emissive [CoIII(CN)6]3- linker can modulate both the magnetic and optical properties of DyIII, being a good sensitizer for DyIII emission, and extorting the axially elongated geometry of DyIII complexes. Recently, we presented also the layered DyIII(4-hydroxypyridine)-[CoIII(CN)6]3- material in which another attractive luminescent property, that is the excitation switchable emission, originating from the equilibrium between properties of DyIII and organic ligand, can be induced within the cyanido-bridged skeleton, and such a property coexists with a field-induced slow magnetic relaxation. elements.content: Europium­(III) chloride hexahydrate (EuIIICl3·6H2O, CAS: 13759-92-7), terbium­(III) chloride hexahydrate (TbIIICl3·6H2O, CAS: 13798-24-8), potassium hexacyanocobaltate­(III) (K3[CoIII(CN)6], CAS: 13963-58-1), and 3-hydroxypyridine (3-OHpy, 3-pyridinol, CAS: 109-00-2) were reagent grade and purchased from commercial sources (Wako Pure Chemical Industries, Ltd. and Sigma-Aldrich) and used without additional purification.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials

Europium(III) chloride hexahydrate (EuIIICl3⋅6H2O, CAS: 13759-92-7), terbium(III) chloride hexahydrate (TbIIICl3⋅6H2O, CAS: 13798-24-8), potassium hexacyanocobaltate(III) (K3[CoIII(CN)6], CAS: 13963-58-1), and 3-hydroxypyridine (3-OHpy, 3-pyridinol, CAS: 109-00-2) were reagent grade and purchased from commercial sources (Wako Pure Chemical Industries, Ltd. and Sigma-Aldrich) and used without additional purification.

elements.content: 1 was synthesized using the following procedure: The 300 mg (0.9 mmol) portion of K3[CoIII(CN)6] was dissolved in 2 mL of water, and the resulting light yellow solution A was stirred for a few minutes. The 220 mg (0.6 mmol) portion of EuIIICl3·6H2O and the 115 mg (1.2 mmol) portion of 3-OHpy were combined together with 2.5 mL of water. The resulting mixture was stirred with continuous heating up to the boiling point to obtain the colorless solution B. Hot solution B was quickly added to the cold solution A giving a small amount of white precipitate which was separated by filtration. The resulting light yellow solution was closed and left for crystallization for 3 h. Then, the block shaped crystals of 1 were collected by filtration, washed by a small amount of cold water, and later heavily with ethanol which was followed by drying the crystals in the air. The crystals of 1 were air-stable, and their composition was found by the single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis, supported by the CHN and metals (ICP-MS) elemental analyses. Yield was calculated based on lanthanide as the excess of K3[CoIII(CN)6] was used. We found that the simple 1:1 molar ratio between CoIII and EuIII resulted in the crystals of the moderate quality which was improved by the addition of extra K3[CoIII(CN)6] precursor.
elements.clean_text:
Synthetic Procedure

 1 was synthesized using the following procedure: The 300 mg (0.9 mmol) portion of K3[CoIII(CN)6] was dissolved in 2 mL of water, and the resulting light yellow solution A was stirred for a few minutes. The 220 mg (0.6 mmol) portion of EuIIICl3⋅6H2O and the 115 mg (1.2 mmol) portion of 3-OHpy were combined together with 2.5 mL of water. The resulting mixture was stirred with continuous heating up to the boiling point to obtain the colorless solution B. Hot solution B was quickly added to the cold solution A giving a small amount of white precipitate which was separated by filtration. The resulting light yellow solution was closed and left for crystallization for 3 h. Then, the block shaped crystals of 1 were collected by filtration, washed by a small amount of cold water, and later heavily with ethanol which was followed by drying the crystals in the air. The crystals of 1 were air-stable, and their composition was found by the single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis, supported by the CHN and metals (ICP-MS) elemental analyses. Yield was calculated based on lanthanide as the excess of K3[CoIII(CN)6] was used. We found that the simple 1:1 molar ratio between CoIII and EuIII resulted in the crystals of the moderate quality which was improved by the addition of extra K3[CoIII(CN)6] precursor.

elements.content: All other compounds, 2–8, were prepared following the analogous procedure as described for 1, using the appropriate mixture of EuIIICl3·6H2O and TbIIICl3·6H2O, keeping the total 0.6 mmol portion of lanthanide­(III) salts. The observations and the treatment of the product during the synthesis and basic characterization of 2–8 were identical to that presented for 1. As was proved by the elemental analysis of CHN and metals (ICP-MS), the compositions of 1–8 correspond well to the formulas expected from the molar ratios between metal ions used in the synthesis. Taking into account the experimental limitations of the elemental analyses, the deviations from the presented amounts of Eu and Tb metal ions per one Co center are estimated to be <0.02.

elements.content: Single-crystal diffraction measurements were performed for 1, 3, and 8 using a Rigaku R-AXIS RAPID imaging plate area detector with graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation. The single crystals were taken from the mother solution, dispersed in a paratone N-oil, mounted on Micro Mounts holder, and measured at the temperature of 100(2) K. The crystal structures were solved by a direct method using SHELXS-97 and refined by a full-matrix least-squares technique using a SHELXL-2014/7. Calculations were performed using partially Crystal Structure crystallographic software and partially WinGX (ver. 1.80.05) integrated system. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms in all structures were found independently from the electron density map. The hydrogen atoms of pyridine rings were refined isotropically, while those of hydroxyl groups and water molecules were refined isotropically using a riding model, with the O–H positions restrained by a DFIX command. In addition, the ISOR restraint was used for one disordered C atom of cyanide in the crystal structure of 8 obtained from the lowest quality data. Structural diagrams were prepared using Mercury 3.8 software. CCDC reference numbers for 1, 3, and 8, are 1526497, 1526499, and 1526498, respectively. Powder diffraction measurements of the air-dried polycrystalline samples of 1–8 were collected on a Rigaku Ultima-IV with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.541 Å).
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

Single-crystal diffraction measurements were performed for 1, 3, and 8 using a Rigaku R-AXIS RAPID imaging plate area detector with graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation. The single crystals were taken from the mother solution, dispersed in a paratone N-oil, mounted on Micro Mounts holder, and measured at the temperature of 100(2) K. The crystal structures were solved by a direct method using SHELXS-97 and refined by a full-matrix least-squares technique using a SHELXL-2014/7. Calculations were performed using partially Crystal Structure crystallographic software and partially WinGX (ver. 1.80.05) integrated system. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The hydrogen atoms in all structures were found independently from the electron density map. The hydrogen atoms of pyridine rings were refined isotropically, while those of hydroxyl groups and water molecules were refined isotropically using a riding model, with the O-H positions restrained by a DFIX command. In addition, the ISOR restraint was used for one disordered C atom of cyanide in the crystal structure of 8 obtained from the lowest quality data. Structural diagrams were prepared using Mercury 3.8 software. CCDC reference numbers for 1, 3, and 8, are 1526497, 1526499, and 1526498, respectively. Powder diffraction measurements of the air-dried polycrystalline samples of 1-8 were collected on a Rigaku Ultima-IV with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.541 Å).

elements.content: Infrared absorption spectra of the polycrystalline samples of 1–8, that were mixed and pressed with carefully dried potassium bromide, were collected using a JASCO FTIR-4100 spectrometer. Infrared spectra of the respective single crystals were collected using a Nicolet iN10 MX FTIR microscope, settled in a transmission mode. Elemental analysis of metal ions (Eu3+, Tb3+, Co3+) was performed using Agilent 7700 ICP-MS mass spectrometer. The CHN analysis was performed using a standard microanalytical method. Thermogravimetric analyses were executed using a Rigaku Thermo Plus TG8120 apparatus in the 20–400 °C range under an air atmosphere with a heating rate of 1 °C, taking aluminum oxide as a reference material. UV–vis-NIR diffuse reflectance (absorption) spectra were collected using a JASCO V-670 spectrophotometer on the polycrystalline samples grinded with barium sulfate. Emission and excitation spectra were measured on a Horiba Jobin-Yvon Fluorolog-3 (FL3-211) spectrofluorimeter (model TKN-7) equipped with an Xe (450 W) lamp as an excitation source with the room-temperature R928P emission detector working in a photon-counting mode. The background correction and the further analyses of the emission and excitation spectra were performed using a Fluoressence software. The luminescent measurements were executed at room temperature in the standard solid-state holder and at a low temperature of 77 K using the optical cryostat cooled by liquid nitrogen. Magnetic studies were performed using a Quantum Design MPMS XL magnetometer on the polycrystalline samples submerged in a paraffin oil to avoid the rotation of crystals under an applied magnetic field. The diamagnetic contributions from the sample, oil, and the holder were estimated and subtracted.

Physical Techniques

Infrared absorption spectra of the polycrystalline samples of 1-8, that were mixed and pressed with carefully dried potassium bromide, were collected using a JASCO FTIR-4100 spectrometer. Infrared spectra of the respective single crystals were collected using a Nicolet iN10 MX FTIR microscope, settled in a transmission mode. Elemental analysis of metal ions (Eu3+, Tb3+, Co3+) was performed using Agilent 7700 ICP-MS mass spectrometer. The CHN analysis was performed using a standard microanalytical method. Thermogravimetric analyses were executed using a Rigaku Thermo Plus TG8120 apparatus in the 20-400 °C range under an air atmosphere with a heating rate of 1 °C, taking aluminum oxide as a reference material. UV-vis-NIR diffuse reflectance (absorption) spectra were collected using a JASCO V-670 spectrophotometer on the polycrystalline samples grinded with barium sulfate. Emission and excitation spectra were measured on a Horiba Jobin-Yvon Fluorolog-3 (FL3-211) spectrofluorimeter (model TKN-7) equipped with an Xe (450 W) lamp as an excitation source with the room-temperature R928P emission detector working in a photon-counting mode. The background correction and the further analyses of the emission and excitation spectra were performed using a Fluoressence software. The luminescent measurements were executed at room temperature in the standard solid-state holder and at a low temperature of 77 K using the optical cryostat cooled by liquid nitrogen. Magnetic studies were performed using a Quantum Design MPMS XL magnetometer on the polycrystalline samples submerged in a paraffin oil to avoid the rotation of crystals under an applied magnetic field. The diamagnetic contributions from the sample, oil, and the holder were estimated and subtracted.

elements.content: The colorless block-shaped single crystals of 1–8 were prepared by the crystallization from the aqueous solution containing the appropriate mixture of EuIIICl3·6H2O with TbIIICl3·6H2O, 3-OHpy ligand, and K3[CoIII(CN)6] (see for details). The single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis was performed for three selected compounds, 1, 3, and 8 ( and S1–S3 and and S1–S4), while the whole series of 1–8 were investigated by means of a powder X-ray diffraction technique showing the perfect isostructurality of all these compounds ( and S5). The representative structural views of the crystal structure of 1 are shown in and S3–S4. 1 is constructed of a cyanido-bridged zigzag chain composed of eight-coordinated [EuIII(μ-NC)2(3-OHpy)2(H2O)4]+ complexes alternately arranged with [CoIII(CN)6]3– units (a). The Eu complex reveals the geometry of elongated dodecahedron, while the Co complex is an almost ideal octahedron (Tables S1 and S2). The coordination chains of 1 are aligned in parallel along [101] axis (bc), and their position in the supramolecular network is stabilized by hydrogen bonds involving cyanides, 3-OHpy, and both coordinated and crystallization water molecules (Figure S4 and Table S3). The powder X-ray diffraction experiment confirmed that the structural model obtained from the single crystal is valid for the bulk polycrystalline sample (Figure S5). In addition, the IR spectrum collected in the broad 750–4000 cm–1 range for the single crystal of 1 overlaps well with the IR spectrum measured for the respective powder sample (Figure S6). This, together with the PXRD studies, confirms the purity of the polycrystalline sample of 1, used in all physical measurements.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structural Studies

The colorless block-shaped single crystals of 1-8 were prepared by the crystallization from the aqueous solution containing the appropriate mixture of EuIIICl3⋅6H2O with TbIIICl3⋅6H2O, 3-OHpy ligand, and K3[CoIII(CN)6] (see  for details). The single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis was performed for three selected compounds, 1, 3, and 8 ( and S1-S3 and  and S1-S4), while the whole series of 1-8 were investigated by means of a powder X-ray diffraction technique showing the perfect isostructurality of all these compounds ( and S5). The representative structural views of the crystal structure of 1 are shown in  and S3-S4. 1 is constructed of a cyanido-bridged zigzag chain composed of eight-coordinated [EuIII(μ-NC)2(3-OHpy)2(H2O)4]+ complexes alternately arranged with [CoIII(CN)6]3- units (a). The Eu complex reveals the geometry of elongated dodecahedron, while the Co complex is an almost ideal octahedron (Tables S1 and S2). The coordination chains of 1 are aligned in parallel along [101] axis (bc), and their position in the supramolecular network is stabilized by hydrogen bonds involving cyanides, 3-OHpy, and both coordinated and crystallization water molecules (Figure S4 and Table S3). The powder X-ray diffraction experiment confirmed that the structural model obtained from the single crystal is valid for the bulk polycrystalline sample (Figure S5). In addition, the IR spectrum collected in the broad 750-4000 cm-1 range for the single crystal of 1 overlaps well with the IR spectrum measured for the respective powder sample (Figure S6). This, together with the PXRD studies, confirms the purity of the polycrystalline sample of 1, used in all physical measurements.

elements.content: Experimental powder X-ray diffraction patterns of 1–8 (a) together with the enlargement of the representative 2Θ range of 17–27° (b), showing the continuous change of the peaks’ positions upon gradual replacement of Eu with Tb from 1–8.

elements.content: The single-crystal X-ray diffraction experiments were also performed for 3 and 8, and the resulting data indicated the perfect isostructurality of these compounds with 1 (Figures S1–S3 and Tables S1–S3). The only subtle differences exist in the detailed metric parameters of bond lengths and angles which originate from the increasing amount of TbIII, revealing the slightly smaller ionic radius than EuIII (Table S1). The validity of the structural model from the respective single crystals to the polycrystalline samples was also checked for 3 and 8 by a powder X-ray diffraction method (Figure S5). This, together with the good matching of the IR spectra of the single crystals and the respective powder samples, indicates the purity of the bulk polycrystalline samples of 3 and 8 (Figure S6). In addition, the precise powder X-ray diffraction data were collected for all the compounds, 1–8, and the resulting patterns were found to be identical, which proves the isostructurality of all these phases (a). Thus, 1–8 are composed of the analogous cyanido-bridged zigzag chains with [CoIII(CN)6]3– anions alternately arranged with lanthanide­(III) complexes of EuIII and TbIII standing at the same crystallographic position with partial occupancies. Only the small continuous shifts of the peaks’ positions upon gradual replacement of Eu with Tb were noticed, which are connected with the increasing size of the unit cell due to the difference in the ionic radius between EuIII and TbIII (b). More importantly, all the compounds showed the individual, not split or broadened, diffraction peaks, indicating that all the obtained crystalline materials are homogeneous and consist of crystals with the identical composition. This means that the Eu and Tb centers are randomly arranged in the coordination chains, keeping the overall Eu/Tb ratio within the whole crystalline phase.
elements.clean_text: The single-crystal X-ray diffraction experiments were also performed for 3 and 8, and the resulting data indicated the perfect isostructurality of these compounds with 1 (Figures S1-S3 and Tables S1-S3). The only subtle differences exist in the detailed metric parameters of bond lengths and angles which originate from the increasing amount of TbIII, revealing the slightly smaller ionic radius than EuIII (Table S1). The validity of the structural model from the respective single crystals to the polycrystalline samples was also checked for 3 and 8 by a powder X-ray diffraction method (Figure S5). This, together with the good matching of the IR spectra of the single crystals and the respective powder samples, indicates the purity of the bulk polycrystalline samples of 3 and 8 (Figure S6). In addition, the precise powder X-ray diffraction data were collected for all the compounds, 1-8, and the resulting patterns were found to be identical, which proves the isostructurality of all these phases (a). Thus, 1-8 are composed of the analogous cyanido-bridged zigzag chains with [CoIII(CN)6]3- anions alternately arranged with lanthanide(III) complexes of EuIII and TbIII standing at the same crystallographic position with partial occupancies. Only the small continuous shifts of the peaks' positions upon gradual replacement of Eu with Tb were noticed, which are connected with the increasing size of the unit cell due to the difference in the ionic radius between EuIII and TbIII (b). More importantly, all the compounds showed the individual, not split or broadened, diffraction peaks, indicating that all the obtained crystalline materials are homogeneous and consist of crystals with the identical composition. This means that the Eu and Tb centers are randomly arranged in the coordination chains, keeping the overall Eu/Tb ratio within the whole crystalline phase.

elements.content: The thermal stability of the polycrystalline samples of 1–8 was investigated by means of thermogravimetric technique in the temperature range of 20–400 °C, and the results are presented in Figure S7. All the compounds, 1–8, reveal very similar thermal stability with a stable composition up to heating to ca. 85–90 °C. On further increase of temperature, the weights of the samples gradually decrease. This process is independent of the Eu/Tb ratio and occurs in a few subsequent steps of three temperature ranges: 90–110 °C (ca. 6.2% of weight loss), 110–130 °C (ca. 3.1–3.2% of weight loss), and 130–180 °C (ca. 4.5% of weight loss). They all together give a mass loss of ca. 13.8–13.9%, which relates well to the removal of five water molecules corresponding to each lanthanide­(III)-cobalt­(III) pair. Thus, the multistep change in the 90–180 °C region can be assigned to the dehydration of the sample that is the phase transition from the initial {[Tb/Eu­(3-OHpy)2(H2O)4]­[Co­(CN)6]·H2O} n composition to the dehydrated phase with the presumable formula of {[Tb/Eu­(3-OHpy)2]­[Co­(CN)6]} n . Such transition was observed by us in the analogous {[Dy­(3-OHpy)2(H2O)4]­[Co­(CN)6]·H2O} n . The further heating above 180 °C results in a large decrease of the mass connected with the typical loss of cyanides and expected decomposition of 3-OHpy ligands.
elements.clean_text:
Thermogravimetric Analysis

The thermal stability of the polycrystalline samples of 1-8 was investigated by means of thermogravimetric technique in the temperature range of 20-400 °C, and the results are presented in Figure S7. All the compounds, 1-8, reveal very similar thermal stability with a stable composition up to heating to ca. 85-90 °C. On further increase of temperature, the weights of the samples gradually decrease. This process is independent of the Eu/Tb ratio and occurs in a few subsequent steps of three temperature ranges: 90-110 °C (ca. 6.2% of weight loss), 110-130 °C (ca. 3.1-3.2% of weight loss), and 130-180 °C (ca. 4.5% of weight loss). They all together give a mass loss of ca. 13.8-13.9%, which relates well to the removal of five water molecules corresponding to each lanthanide(III)-cobalt(III) pair. Thus, the multistep change in the 90-180 °C region can be assigned to the dehydration of the sample that is the phase transition from the initial {[Tb/Eu(3-OHpy)2(H2O)4][Co(CN)6]⋅H2O} n  composition to the dehydrated phase with the presumable formula of {[Tb/Eu(3-OHpy)2][Co(CN)6]} n . Such transition was observed by us in the analogous {[Dy(3-OHpy)2(H2O)4][Co(CN)6]⋅H2O} n . The further heating above 180 °C results in a large decrease of the mass connected with the typical loss of cyanides and expected decomposition of 3-OHpy ligands.

elements.content: Compounds 1–8 reveal a weak yellowish color which is related to very weak absorption in the visible range and strong UV absorption with three distinct maxima at around 210, 245, and 300 nm (Figure S8). The positions of these maxima are very similar in all compounds, 1–8, which means that they are related to the absorption properties of 3-OHpy and [CoIII(CN)6]3– moieties, as EuIII and TbIII are known to reveal weak UV–vis absorption due to the spin- and parity-forbidden character of their f–f transitions. The deep UV maximum at 210 nm can be assigned to the combined contributions from d–d 1A1g → 1Eg transition of CoIII and singlet to singlet (π → π*) transition of 3-OHpy (Figure S9). The UV maximum at 245 nm is related to the d–d 1A1g → 1T2g transition of CoIII while the maximum at 300 nm to another d–d transition of CoIII, that is 1A1g → 1T1g. The singlet to singlet (π → π*) transitions of 3-OHpy also contribute to these two UV bands of 1–8. The strong UV absorption is only followed by the much weaker absorption tail to ca. 400 nm which is responsible for the overall yellow color of the samples and can be assigned to the spin-forbidden transitions: 1A1g → 3T1g of CoIII and singlet to triplet (π → π*) of 3-OHpy (Figure S9). Above 400 nm, compounds 1–8 show only very weak absorption peaks related to the f–f transitions of lanthanides­(III) complexes (Figure S10). In EuIII-based 1, three absorption peaks are observed at 464, 534, and 578 nm, and they can be ascribed to the electronic transitions from the 7F0 ground state to the 5D2, 5D1, and 5D0 excited states, respectively. In TbIII-based 8, one distinct absorption peak at 486 nm, assignable to the 7F6 → 5D4 transition, is observed. In the mixed Eu/Tb compounds, a mixture of EuIII- and TbIII-based bands are detected, however, they are extremely weak and do not affect the color of the materials.

elements.content: Due to strong UV and very weak visible absorption, compounds 1–8 reveal the significant solid-state photoluminescence in the visible range under the UV excitation. The low-temperature (T = 77 K) emission spectra of 1–8 upon the UV excitation of 376 nm are presented in . Under such an excitation wavelength, 1 exhibits red photoluminescence related to f–f electronic transitions of EuIII, from the 5D0 emissive state to a series of 7F0,1,2,3,4 multiplets, giving the maxima at 578, 588, 618, 650, and 698 nm, respectively (a). The excitation spectrum of 1 for the monitored emission of 618 nm is composed of the combined contributions from 3-OHpy and [CoIII(CN)6]3–, giving the broad and complex band centered at 330 nm and the additional Eu3+-based sharp peaks developing from the broad component above 350 nm. This indicates the occurrence of an energy-transfer process from both ligand and CoIII to EuIII. Such interpretation is supported by the disappearance of ligand- and Co-based emission bands expected in the green and red regions of the spectrum, respectively (Figure S11). Similar ligand-to-metal and metal-to-metal energy-transfer effects are also observed in 8, revealing the green emission which originates from the series of 5D4 → 7F6,5,4,3,2,1,0 electronic transitions of TbIII resulting in the maxima at 490, 545, 584, 622, 646, 660, and 680 nm, respectively (b). The excitation spectrum of 8 consists of two distinguishable parts that are a broad band centered at 315 nm, related to 3-OHpy and Co3+, and the lower energy complex band with three distinct peaks at 356, 368, and 377 nm which mainly correspond to Tb3+-based electronic transitions. This, together with the lack of both ligand- and Co-based emission (Figure S11), indicated that both the energy-transfer and the direct excitation pathways are achievable in 8.

elements.content: Upon UV excitation by the 376 nm light, the mixed trimetallic Eu/Tb/Co compounds, 2–7, exhibit diverse multicolored photoluminescence dependent on the metal ratio between Eu3+ and Tb3+, which give red and green emission components, respectively (c,d). In general, both Eu and Tb emission peaks exist in all the mixed compounds, and their excitation spectra are similar to those detected for Eu-based 1 and Tb-based 8, depending on the respective monitored emission wavelengths. This indicates that Eu and Tb emission processes are rather independent, and the lanthanide-to-lanthanide energy-transfer effect is not observed. However, at the experimental temperature of 77 K, Eu-based emission is slightly stronger than the Tb-centered one, as visible in the ratio between the main maxima at 618 and 545 nm, respectively, in 5, constructed of the equimolar amount of Eu and Tb (c). Thus, 5 reveals the emission of orange color, closer to purely Eu-based than Tb-based emission. It was possible to adjust the Eu/Tb ratio where various emission colors ranging from green to red, through yellow and orange, were achieved for compounds 2–7, as shown on the CIE 1931 chromaticity diagram (d). The detailed xy parameters of the resulting emission colors of 1–8 are gathered in Table S4.

elements.content: As proved by the low-temperature excitation spectra shown in , both EuIII and TbIII are sensitized by the coordinated 3-OHpy ligand and [CoIII(CN)6]3– moieties. However, the excitation spectra of the mixed Eu/Tb/Co compounds differ depending on the monitored emission signals of EuIII (λem = 618 nm) and TbIII (λem = 546 nm, c). This is caused by the very different direct excitation pathways for EuIII and TbIII which are related to the various high-energy excited states of these two lanthanides­(3+) ions. In addition, the broad UV-excitation components are also significantly different for EuIII and TbIII emission peaks. For Tb3+ emission, the main excitation peak is centered around 315 nm, and the second band is only growing from ca. 330 nm toward the visible range. For Eu3+ emission, the broad UV excitation band is continuously growing from 250 nm to the visible range with a distinguishable maximum around 330 nm. Such differences can be explained by the different efficiencies of energy-transfer processes from 3-OHpy and CoIII to EuIII and TbIII. It is generally difficult to judge which of two sensitizers, organic ligand or hexacyanide complex, is better for EuIII or TbIII, as they exhibit very similar excitation spectra (Figure S11). However, the [CoIII(CN)6]3– ion reveals lower energy emission, ranging from 550 to 800 nm, than 3-OHpy showing an emission peak from 400 to 650 nm (Figure S11). It indicates that the 3-OHpy ligand, due to the better energy matching, can be more suitable for sensitization of TbIII, revealing the higher energy emission starting with the peak at 490 nm, while [CoIII(CN)6]3– may be better for the sensitization of EuIII, exhibiting red luminescence with the lowest energy peak at 576 nm.

elements.content: Taking advantage of the different patterns of excitation spectra for EuIII and TbIII embedded in the trimetallic compounds, 2–7, we investigated the low-temperature photoluminescent properties under various UV-excitation wavelengths ( and and S12–S15). Whereas for 2 and 3, containing the large amount of Eu3+, the photoluminescence was found to be generally dominated by the red component of Eu3+, and the compound 4 reveals the visible emission with color ranging from yellow to deep red with the hues of various CIE 1931 xy parameters depending on the excitation wavelength ( and S12 and Table S5). For 4, the deep UV light between 250 and 300 nm induces the emission processes of EuIII and TbIII almost equally, resulting in yellow to light orange emission colors (, Table S5). The lower energy excitation by various wavelengths of UV light above 310 nm produces the domination of Eu-based red emission, but the detailed ratio between Eu3+- and Tb3+-centered peaks is variable, giving a series of different hues of orange to red colors. Among them, the purest red emission of x = 0.62 and y = 0.35 CIE 1931 parameters is detected for the 324 nm light, for which Tb3+ luminescence is not induced.

elements.content: Compounds 5–7 also exhibit multicolored excitation-dependent photoluminescence, however, all the emission colors are gradually shifted toward green emission related to the growing intensity of Tb-based component ( and S13–S15). For 5 and 6, the excitation-variable emission ranges from yellowish green to deep orange with a lot of diverse hues of the CIE 1931 chromaticity parameters (Table S5). Compound 7, containing the large excess of Tb, exhibits the nearly pure green emission of x = 0.36 and y = 0.58 CIE 1931 parameters at deep UV excitation below 300 nm, as these wavelengths excite mainly Tb3+. The yellowish green and yellow emissions, related to the dominated Tb3+ emission, are achieved for the excitation by the UV light in the range of 300–320 nm due the effective energy-transfer process to Tb and in the range of 370–380 nm due to the strong direct f-centered excitation pathway for Tb (). For other UV excitation regions, Eu-based red emission starts to dominate giving orange luminescence of the various hues, up to that close to red color. The xy parameters of the CIE 1931 chromaticity scale obtained for all compounds under various selected UV excitation wavelengths are gathered in Table S5.

elements.content: The solid-state photoluminescent properties were also observed for trimetallic Eu/Tb/Co compounds, 2–7, at room temperature. However, at this temperature, the emission is overwhelmingly dominated by a red Eu-based component, as depicted by the excitation-variable emission spectra for 7 showing nearly the identical red color for the whole 200–400 nm range of UV excitation (Figure S16). This indicates that the emission of Eu3+ ions embedded in the chain structure of 1–8 is much stronger at room temperature than of the analogous complexes of Tb3+. However, the Tb-based emission is growing much faster than the Eu3+ one upon cooling, and at a low temperature of 77 K, it was possible to find the equilibrium between Tb and Eu emission components as shown above.

elements.content: The direct-current (dc) magnetic properties of 1–8 are presented in . The room-temperature χM T value of EuIII-containing 1 is 1.5 cm3 mol–1 K, which perfectly suits to 1.5 cm3 mol–1 K predicted for the EuIII center separated by diamagnetic [CoIII(CN)6]3– moieties. In fact, the europium­(3+) ion reveals the diamagnetic 7F0 ground state, but its 7F1 and 7F2 paramagnetic excited states are located close in energy and can be thermally populated giving a nonzero contribution to the χM T. However, the population of the excited states is gradually decreasing on cooling, thus at 1.8 K, only the diamagnetic 7F0 ground state is occupied. This is well documented in the continuous decrease of the χM T on cooling to the low value of 0.02 cm3 mol–1 K at 1.8 K (a) and by the very slow increase of molar magnetization up to only 0.05 μB at H = 50 kOe (b). Assuming the occurrence of thermal depopulation of 7FJ excited states of Eu3+ in 1 that originates from the spin–orbit coupling (SOC) splitting, we simulated the χM T–T plot with the SOC constant (λ) as a fitting parameter ( and S17, see also Supporting Information for details). Satisfactory agreement with the experiment was obtained for λ = 304(4) cm–1, the slightly lower value as compared with EuIII complexes embedded in other cyanido-bridged bimetallic systems. Thus, at very low temperature, 1 behaves almost as a diamagnet with only residual magnetic signal. This precludes any possibility to observe long-range magnetic ordering or slow magnetic relaxation on EuIII complexes in 1.

Magnetic Properties

The direct-current (dc) magnetic properties of 1-8 are presented in . The room-temperature χM T value of EuIII-containing 1 is 1.5 cm3 mol-1 K, which perfectly suits to 1.5 cm3 mol-1 K predicted for the EuIII center separated by diamagnetic [CoIII(CN)6]3- moieties. In fact, the europium(3+) ion reveals the diamagnetic 7F0 ground state, but its 7F1 and 7F2 paramagnetic excited states are located close in energy and can be thermally populated giving a nonzero contribution to the χM T. However, the population of the excited states is gradually decreasing on cooling, thus at 1.8 K, only the diamagnetic 7F0 ground state is occupied. This is well documented in the continuous decrease of the χM T on cooling to the low value of 0.02 cm3 mol-1 K at 1.8 K (a) and by the very slow increase of molar magnetization up to only 0.05 μB at H = 50 kOe (b). Assuming the occurrence of thermal depopulation of 7FJ excited states of Eu3+ in 1 that originates from the spin-orbit coupling (SOC) splitting, we simulated the χM T-T plot with the SOC constant (λ) as a fitting parameter ( and S17, see also Supporting Information for details). Satisfactory agreement with the experiment was obtained for λ = 304(4) cm-1, the slightly lower value as compared with EuIII complexes embedded in other cyanido-bridged bimetallic systems. Thus, at very low temperature, 1 behaves almost as a diamagnet with only residual magnetic signal. This precludes any possibility to observe long-range magnetic ordering or slow magnetic relaxation on EuIII complexes in 1.

elements.content: On the contrary, TbIII-containing compound 8 exhibits the high χM T value of 11.5 cm3 mol–1 K at room temperature. This value is only slightly lower than 11.8 cm3 mol–1 K calculated for uncoupled TbIII of the 7F6 ground state (J = 6, g J = 3/2) separated by diamagnetic [CoIII(CN)6]3–. Upon cooling, the χM T gradually decreases, first very slowly in the 300–100 K range and later faster, reaching 9.2 cm3 mol–1 K at 1.8 K (a). Such decrease of the magnetic signal can be ascribed mainly to the depopulation of the mJ levels arising from the splitting of the 7F6 ground state of TbIII, while the contribution of weak antiferromagnetic Tb–Tb interactions through diamagnetic [CoIII(CN)6]3–, or through the interchain space, plays a minor role. This is supported by the magnetization versus field curve at T = 1.8 K showing the featureless increase of M reaching 4.9 μB at 50 kOe (b), which is close the value of 5.0 μB expected for typical isolated TbIII magnetic moment described by an effective spin of S eff = 1/2 with the strong uniaxial Ising-type anisotropy of the g-tensor (g ∥ = 10, g ⊥ = 0). No sign of magnetic ordering effect was observed in magnetic data of 8 down to 1.8 K.

elements.content: The mixed trimetallic Eu/Tb/Co compounds, 2–7, reveal the intermediate values of χM T product and molar magnetization M, depending on the ratio between TbIII showing a high and T-dependent magnetic signal and EuIII exhibiting only weak and also T-dependent paramagnetism with the diamagnetic ground state (). Moreover, the EuIII and TbIII signals can be treated as independent, as these magnetic centers are generally well separated by the diamagnetic [CoIII(CN)6]3– anions within the coordination chains as well as by organic ligands and crystallization water molecules within the interchain space. In addition, EuIII becomes a diamagnetic center at low temperatures, therefore the possible Eu–Tb interactions can be neglected. Thus, the experimental room-temperature values of χM T and molar magnetization at highest available magnetic field of 50 kOe at T = 1.8 K for 2–7 correspond well to those calculated from the values measured for 1 and 8 taking into account the appropriate Eu/Tb ratio. In fact, the whole χM T(T) and M(H) plots of 2–7 follow well the respective curves calculated based on the analogous dependences of 1 and 8, taking into account the molar contributions of Eu and Tb (Figure S18). This additionally proves that the EuIII and TbIII magnetic signals in 2–7 are practically independent and reveal the paramagnetic behavior without any sign of magnetic ordering down to 1.8 K.

Moreover, the EuIII and TbIII signals can be treated as independent, as these magnetic centers are generally well separated by the diamagnetic [CoIII(CN)6]3- anions within the coordination chains as well as by organic ligands and crystallization water molecules within the interchain space. elements.content: As EuIII is diamagnetic at low temperatures, the observation of slow magnetic relaxation was only possible in the compounds containing paramagnetic TbIII, which magnetic anisotropy often leads to a single-molecule magnet behavior. Therefore, alternate current (ac) magnetic properties were first examined for bimetallic Tb–Co compound 8, and the results are presented in and S19. In the zero dc field, the out-of-phase magnetic susceptibility, χM″, is negligibly small, even at a low temperature of 1.85 K, but becomes noticeable above a dc field of 200 Oe (Figure S19). An optimal dc field of 1500 Oe clearly induces the slow relaxation of magnetization effect as presented by the significant signals in the χM′(ν) and χM″(ν) plots at various temperatures below 5 K (). 8 exhibits two relaxation processes that are slow relaxation related to the maxima of χM″(ν) plots around 10 Hz and the faster relaxation represented by the onset of the second contributions at higher frequencies, with the presumable maxima just above the available frequency limit of 1500 Hz (b). The frequency dependences of both χM′ and χM″ together with the related Argand χM″(χM′) plots at selected temperatures from the 1.85–4.2 K range could be analyzed using the generalized Debye model for the limited range of lower frequencies corresponding to the slower relaxation (a–c and Table S6). The resulting Cole–Cole parameters, α, are within the range of 0.48–0.61, indicating the broad distribution of relaxation times. The relaxation times, τ, were plotted in function of temperature as ln­(τ) versus T –1 (d) which show that the slower relaxation process is temperature independent with no assignable thermal energy barrier. On the contrary, the visual inspection of the detected onsets of the signals of the faster relaxation suggests that this second process is presumably strongly temperature dependent, especially within the 3.5–5 K range where the signal is strongly shifting toward higher frequencies (b). Due to the lack of clear maxima in the χM″(ν) plots in the available frequency range, the detailed analysis of ac dynamic parameters could not be reasonably performed. Thus, it is difficult to discuss the origin of a double relaxation process observed in 8. However, as 8 reveals only one symmetrically independent Tb3+ ion, the field-induced two-step relaxation process cannot be ascribed to purely single-ion properties of two distinguishable Tb complexes of different geometries. Therefore, the faster relaxation that is presumably T-dependent could be assigned to the standard single-ion property of TbIII complex, while the slower and T-independent relaxation might be induced by magnetic dipole–magnetic dipole interactions, as postulated in various lanthanide­(III)-based SMMs, including the cyanido-bridged coordination polymers. Such effect is possible due to the lattice vibrations that modify distances between magnetic ions affecting the magnetic field produced by a dipole at a neighboring one. As a result, one magnetic ion behaves as an induced dipolar field influencing the relaxation process of the another center. This effect is usually related to the intermetallic Tb–Tb distances not long enough to isolate Tb3+ efficiently. Thus, it seems that the shortest Tb–Tb distances of ca. 8 Å in 8 are not capable to completely cancel the influence of one Tb center on the neighboring ones.

elements.content: To confirm such interpretation, we performed the analogous ac magnetic studies on compounds 2–7, consisting of Tb3+ ions separated not only by diamagnetic [CoIII(CN)6]3– moieties but also by the increasing amount of Eu3+ revealing a diamagnetic ground state. With an increasing amount of Eu on going from 7 to 2, we observed the gradual disappearance of the slower relaxation process, which is only residual in the case of 2, where Tb3+ occupies only 20% of positions available for lanthanide­(III) complexes (). This material can be considered as a magnetically diluted sample of 8, as the Tb–Tb distances are expected to be much longer. As a result, 2 reveals a nearly single field-induced relaxation process, while the second relaxation appears only as a weak tail existing in the χM″(ν) plots at lower frequencies. The limited ac magnetic data for an optimal dc field of 1500 Oe were analyzed using the Debye model for a single relaxation (a–c and S20 and Table S7). The obtained α-parameters of 0.16–0.26 indicated a much narrower distribution of relaxation times than in 8. The relaxation times obey the Arrhenius law above 3.5 K, giving the energy barrier, ΔE/k B of 35.8(6) K with τ0 = 1.1(2) × 10–8 s, clearly proving the field-induced SMM character of TbIII complexes embedded in the cyanido-bridged chains of 1–8. As 2 still revealed the residual ac magnetic signal originating from the second relaxation process, we prepared the additional, more magnetically diluted analog of 1–8, with Tb3+ occupying only 5% of all the positions available for trivalent lanthanide ions (see Supporting Information for details). This sample, Eu 095 Tb 0.05 Co, was characterized by CHN and metals elemental analyses, which, together with the PXRD pattern, indicated the perfect isostructurality with 1–8 and the composition of {[EuIII 0.95TbIII 0.05(3-OHpy)2(H2O)4]­[CoIII(CN)6]·H2O} n (Figure S21). Its dc magnetic properties correspond well to the expected presence of 5% of TbIII and 95% of EuIII centers at lanthanide positions (Figure S22). More importantly, Eu 095 Tb 0.05 Co exhibits a clearly single, field-induced relaxation process which was analyzed using the Debye model for the whole available frequency range (Figure S23 and Table S8). The resulting relaxation times obey the Arrhenius law above 3.5 K, giving the energy barrier, ΔE/k B = 39.1(5) K, and the pre-exponential factor, τ0 = 7.7(4)·10–9 s, both comparable with the values found in 2. These additionally confirm that the investigated TbIII complexes behave as single-molecule magnets giving the temperature-dependent relaxation process. The second, T-independent relaxation at lower frequencies is vanishing on a magnetic dilution due to the decreased dipole–dipole interactions between neighboring TbIII centers.

elements.content: We present a unique family of bifunctional materials combining tunable visible photoluminescence and single-molecule magnet characteristics. The reported family of crystalline materials are constructed of trimetallic cyanido-bridged chains, EuIII x TbIII 1–x (3-OHpy)-CoIII (x = 1, 0.8, 0.5, 0.3, 0.2, 0.1, 0; compounds 1, 2, ..., 7, 8). They reveal multicolored, green to red, UV-light-induced emission tunable by the composition and by the excitation wavelength. We explored here both the direct excitation pathways through highly lying f-electronic states, different for Eu3+ and Tb3+, and the excitation of [CoIII(CN)6]3– and 3-OHpy chromophores, which transfer the energy to Eu and Tb with distinguishable efficiencies. Besides the attractive optical properties, 1–8 exhibit temperature-dependent paramagnetism and the field-induced slow relaxation of magnetization due to the magnetic anisotropy of Tb3+, along with the strong quantum tunneling of magnetization effect, limiting the relaxation processes at zero dc field. The compounds with the large amount of Tb reveal two relaxation processes, the faster of a typical single-ion origin and the second coming from the magnetic dipole–magnetic dipole interaction. This second process disappears due to the magnetic dilution by the excess of Eu3+. As a result Eu0.8Tb0.2Co material, 2, shows a nearly single relaxation process, indicating a SMM character.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

We present a unique family of bifunctional materials combining tunable visible photoluminescence and single-molecule magnet characteristics. The reported family of crystalline materials are constructed of trimetallic cyanido-bridged chains, EuIII  x TbIII 1-x (3-OHpy)-CoIII (x = 1, 0.8, 0.5, 0.3, 0.2, 0.1, 0; compounds 1, 2, ..., 7, 8). They reveal multicolored, green to red, UV-light-induced emission tunable by the composition and by the excitation wavelength. We explored here both the direct excitation pathways through highly lying f-electronic states, different for Eu3+ and Tb3+, and the excitation of [CoIII(CN)6]3- and 3-OHpy chromophores, which transfer the energy to Eu and Tb with distinguishable efficiencies. Besides the attractive optical properties, 1-8 exhibit temperature-dependent paramagnetism and the field-induced slow relaxation of magnetization due to the magnetic anisotropy of Tb3+, along with the strong quantum tunneling of magnetization effect, limiting the relaxation processes at zero dc field. The compounds with the large amount of Tb reveal two relaxation processes, the faster of a typical single-ion origin and the second coming from the magnetic dipole-magnetic dipole interaction. This second process disappears due to the magnetic dilution by the excess of Eu3+. As a result Eu0.8Tb0.2Co material, 2, shows a nearly single relaxation process, indicating a SMM character.

elements.content: The multifunctionality of the reported family of materials is directed and controlled by the rich structural and electronic interaction between lanthanide­(3+) ions, organic ligand, and hexacyanocobaltate­(III). We, thus, uncover a great potential in enhancement and modulation of intrinsic luminescent properties of lanthanides by [CoIII(CN)6]3– anions which control the crystal structure of the material, ensure its thermal stability, and contribute importantly to the tunable photoluminescence by metal-to-metal energy-transfer process. In addition, the hexacyanide complex serves as a diamagnetic linker magnetically separating the anisotropic Tb complexes, opening the possibilities to observe slow magnetic relaxation processes, and, together with organic ligand, modulates the geometry of Tb complexes which is crucial for SMM characteristics. The rather axial geometry induced in compounds 1–8 is, however, not the most appropriate for TbIII complexes, which results in the only moderate energy barrier and a large contribution of the QTM effect. Thus, our future work will be focused on the preparation of coordination systems in which more planar Tb3+ ions, preferable for the more pronounced SMM behavior, can be induced within the cyanido-bridged skeleton. We plan to achieve this by modification of Tb3+ geometry by diverse organic ligands from the family of pyridine- or pyrimidine-based molecules or by the controlled thermal dehydration which can dramatically modify the coordination geometry without changing the cyanido-bridged connectivity. In future work, we also plan to investigate deeply the energy-transfer process from cyanide-based complexes of CoIII to lanthanide­(3+) ions in solid-state materials constructed of related coordination polymers of various topologies to understand the key structural and electronic factors influencing the intensity of resulting f-centered emission. This will give us a better chance to rationally design and prepare functional materials based on heterometallic cyanido-bridged d–f coordination systems to govern both the magnetic and optical functionalities.

cln_elements.content:
The thermal stability of the polycrystalline samples of 1–8 was investigated by means of thermogravimetric technique in the temperature range of 20–400 °C, and the results are presented in Figure S7. All the compounds, 1–8, reveal very similar thermal stability with a stable composition up to heating to ca. 85–90 °C. On further increase of temperature, the weights of the samples gradually decrease. This process is independent of the Eu/Tb ratio and occurs in a few subsequent steps of three temperature ranges: 90–110 °C (ca. 6.2% of weight loss), 110–130 °C (ca. 3.1–3.2% of weight loss), and 130–180 °C (ca. 4.5% of weight loss). They all together give a mass loss of ca. 13.8–13.9%, which relates well to the removal of five water molecules corresponding to each lanthanide­(III)-cobalt­(III) pair. Thus, the multistep change in the 90–180 °C region can be assigned to the dehydration of the sample that is the phase transition from the initial {[Tb/Eu­(3-OHpy)2(H2O)4]­[Co­(CN)6]·H2O} n composition to the dehydrated phase with the presumable formula of {[Tb/Eu­(3-OHpy)2]­[Co­(CN)6]} n . Such transition was observed by us in the analogous {[Dy­(3-OHpy)2(H2O)4]­[Co­(CN)6]·H2O} n . The further heating above 180 °C results in a large decrease of the mass connected with the typical loss of cyanides and expected decomposition of 3-OHpy ligands.

Magnetic Properties

The direct-current (dc) magnetic properties of 1–8 are presented in . The room-temperature χM T value of EuIII-containing 1 is 1.5 cm3 mol–1 K, which perfectly suits to 1.5 cm3 mol–1 K predicted for the EuIII center separated by diamagnetic [CoIII(CN)6]3– moieties. In fact, the europium­(3+) ion reveals the diamagnetic 7F0 ground state, but its 7F1 and 7F2 paramagnetic excited states are located close in energy and can be thermally populated giving a nonzero contribution to the χM T. However, the population of the excited states is gradually decreasing on cooling, thus at 1.8 K, only the diamagnetic 7F0 ground state is occupied. This is well documented in the continuous decrease of the χM T on cooling to the low value of 0.02 cm3 mol–1 K at 1.8 K (a) and by the very slow increase of molar magnetization up to only 0.05 μB at H = 50 kOe (b). Assuming the occurrence of thermal depopulation of 7FJ excited states of Eu3+ in 1 that originates from the spin–orbit coupling (SOC) splitting, we simulated the χM T–T plot with the SOC constant (λ) as a fitting parameter ( and S17, see also Supporting Information for details). Satisfactory agreement with the experiment was obtained for λ = 304(4) cm–1, the slightly lower value as compared with EuIII complexes embedded in other cyanido-bridged bimetallic systems. Thus, at very low temperature, 1 behaves almost as a diamagnet with only residual magnetic signal. This precludes any possibility to observe long-range magnetic ordering or slow magnetic relaxation on EuIII complexes in 1.

On the contrary, TbIII-containing compound 8 exhibits the high χM T value of 11.5 cm3 mol–1 K at room temperature. This value is only slightly lower than 11.8 cm3 mol–1 K calculated for uncoupled TbIII of the 7F6 ground state (J = 6, g J = 3/2) separated by diamagnetic [CoIII(CN)6]3–. Upon cooling, the χM T gradually decreases, first very slowly in the 300–100 K range and later faster, reaching 9.2 cm3 mol–1 K at 1.8 K (a). Such decrease of the magnetic signal can be ascribed mainly to the depopulation of the mJ levels arising from the splitting of the 7F6 ground state of TbIII, while the contribution of weak antiferromagnetic Tb–Tb interactions through diamagnetic [CoIII(CN)6]3–, or through the interchain space, plays a minor role. This is supported by the magnetization versus field curve at T = 1.8 K showing the featureless increase of M reaching 4.9 μB at 50 kOe (b), which is close the value of 5.0 μB expected for typical isolated TbIII magnetic moment described by an effective spin of S eff = 1/2 with the strong uniaxial Ising-type anisotropy of the g-tensor (g ∥ = 10, g ⊥ = 0). No sign of magnetic ordering effect was observed in magnetic data of 8 down to 1.8 K.

The further heating above 180 °C results in a large decrease of the mass connected with the typical loss of cyanides and expected decomposition of 3-OHpy ligands.
